head.title: Frobenius-Perron Resonances for Maps with a Mixed Phase Space

article.h1: Frobenius-Perron Resonances for Maps with a Mixed Phase Space

span.span: Joachim Weber11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{1}, Fritz Haake11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{1}, and Petr Šeba22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2}
11NUMBER:11 Fachbereich Physik, Universität-GH Essen, 45117 Essen, Germany
22NUMBER:22 Institute of Physics, Czech Academy of Sciences, Prague, Czech Republic

div.p: Resonances of the time evolution (Frobenius-Perron) operator 𝒫𝒫caligraphic-P{\cal P} for phase space densities have recently been shown to play a key role for the interrelations of classical, semiclassical and quantum dynamics. Efficient methods to determine resonances are thus in demand, in particular for Hamiltonian systems displaying a mix of chaotic and regular behavior. We present a powerful method based on truncating 𝒫𝒫caligraphic-P{\cal P} to a finite matrix which not only allows to identify resonances but also the associated phase space structures. It is demonstrated to work well for a prototypical dynamical system.

Effectively irreversible behavior of classical Hamiltonian systems can be elucidated by studying the phase space density and its propagator, the Frobenius-Perron operator 𝒫𝒫caligraphic-P{\cal P}. Due to Liouville’s theorem 𝒫𝒫caligraphic-P{\cal P} can be represented by an infinite unitary matrix whose spectrum lies on the unit circle in the complex plane. Nevertheless, means and correlation functions of observables can relax (see figure 1c) with damping factors known as (Ruelle-Pollicott) resonances [1, 2, 3, 4] of 𝒫𝒫caligraphic-P{\cal P}. These resonances have recently attracted attention, e.g. in a superanalytic approach to universal fluctuations in quantum (quasi-) energy spectra which originated from the physics of disordered systems. In that approach the Frobenius-Perron resonances constitute a link between classical and quantum chaos [5, 6]. There is even a recent experiment where quantum fingerprints of Ruelle-Pollicott resonances are identified [7]. To further clarify the interrelations between classical, semiclassical, and quantum behavior, a practical scheme to actually determine classical resonances is called for which is free of restrictions of previous investigations, like hyperbolicity, one-dimensional (quasi-) phase space or isolation of the phase-space regions causing intermittency.

Our thus motivated quantitative investigations into Hamiltonian systems with mixed phase space, a still largely unexplored area of great interest and promise, lead us to the discrete unimodular Frobenius-Perron eigenvalues (with eigenfunctions localized in islands of regular motion around elliptic periodic orbits, see figure 1a) and to resonances, smaller than unity in modulus (with eigenfunctions localized on the unstable manifolds of hyperbolic periodic orbits, see figure 2a-c). Both the discrete spectrum and the resonances are determined by diagonalizing truncated Frobenius-Perron matrices 𝒫(N)superscript𝒫𝑁caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)} and studying the cut-off dependence of its eigenvalues. Using the information about eigenfunctions, we then reproduce resonances by the so-called cycle expansion of periodic-orbit theory and furthermore through decay rates of correlation functions. We should add that similarly motivated but technically different (not involving eigenfunctions and employing external noise) efforts to determine resonances can be found in Refs. [8, 9, 10].

As a prototypical dynamical system we have employed the kicked top, i.e. a periodically kicked angular momentum J→=(j⁢sin⁡θ⁢cos⁡φ,j⁢sin⁡θ⁢sin⁡φ,j⁢cos⁡θ)→𝐽𝑗𝜃𝜑𝑗𝜃𝜑𝑗𝜃OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-J ARG:end RELOP:equals OPEN:( italic-j TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-theta TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-varphi PUNCT:, italic-j TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-theta TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-varphi PUNCT:, italic-j TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-theta CLOSE:)\vec{J}=(j\sin\theta\cos\varphi,j\sin\theta\sin\varphi,j\cos\theta) of conserved length j𝑗italic-jj whose phase space is the sphere J→2/j2=1superscript→𝐽2superscript𝑗21OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-J ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-j POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\vec{J}^{2}/j^{2}=1; we confront a single degree of freedom with the “azimutal” angle ϕitalic-ϕitalic-phi\phi as the coordinate and the cosine of the “polar” angle θ𝜃italic-theta\theta the conjugate momentum. The dynamics is specified as a stroboscopic area preserving map M𝑀italic-MM on phase space. It consists of rotations Rz⁢(βz),Ry⁢(βy)subscript𝑅𝑧subscript𝛽𝑧subscript𝑅𝑦subscript𝛽𝑦italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:, italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)R_{z}(\beta_{z}),R_{y}(\beta_{y}) about the y-limit-from𝑦italic-y ADDOP:minusy- and z-limit-from𝑧italic-z ADDOP:minusz-axes and a “torsion”, i.e. a nonlinear rotation Rz⁢(τ⁢cos⁡θ)subscript𝑅𝑧𝜏𝜃italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-tau TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-theta CLOSE:)R_{z}(\tau\cos\theta) about the z-limit-from𝑧italic-z ADDOP:minusz-axis which changes φ𝜑italic-varphi\varphi by τ⁢cos⁡θ𝜏𝜃italic-tau TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-theta\tau\cos\theta,

semantics.annotation: italic-M RELOP:equals italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-tau TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-theta CLOSE:) italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: The equivalent map of the phase space density ρ𝜌italic-rho\rho is brought about by the Frobenius-Perron operator 𝒫𝒫caligraphic-P{\cal P},

semantics.annotation: caligraphic-P italic-rho OPEN:( TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-theta PUNCT:, italic-varphi CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-rho OPEN:( italic-M POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-theta PUNCT:, italic-varphi CLOSE:) CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: We keep βz=βy=1subscript𝛽𝑧subscript𝛽𝑦1italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\beta_{z}=\beta_{y}=1 fixed and vary the torsion constant τ𝜏italic-tau\tau, starting with the integrable case τ=0𝜏0italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\tau=0. Increasing values of τ𝜏italic-tau\tau bring about more and more chaos until for τ>10𝜏10italic-tau RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:10\tau>10 elliptic islands have become so small that they are difficult to detect. We shall focus on τ=4𝜏4italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:4\tau=4 (roughly 90%percent90NUMBER:90 POSTFIX:percent90\% of the phase space dominated by chaos) and τ=10𝜏10italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:10\tau=10 (more than 99%percent99NUMBER:99 POSTFIX:percent99\% chaos).

A Hilbert space of phase space functions on the sphere is spanned by the spherical harmonics Yl⁢m⁢(θ,φ)subscript𝑌𝑙𝑚𝜃𝜑italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-l italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-theta PUNCT:, italic-varphi CLOSE:)Y_{lm}(\theta,\varphi) with l=0,1,2,…𝑙012…italic-l RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, ID:dotsl=0,1,2,\dots and |m|≤l𝑚𝑙VERTBAR:| italic-m VERTBAR:| RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-l|m|\leq l. These functions are ordered with respect to phase space resolution by the index l𝑙italic-ll: if all Yl⁢msubscript𝑌𝑙𝑚italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-l italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:endY_{lm} with 0≤l≤lm⁢a⁢x0𝑙subscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥NUMBER:0 RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-l RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end0\leq l\leq l_{max} are admitted phase space structures of area roughly 4⁢π/(lm⁢a⁢x+1)24𝜋superscriptsubscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥12NUMBER:4 italic-pi MULOP:divide OPEN:( italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end4\pi/(l_{max}+1)^{2} can be resolved. If we so truncate the infinite Frobenius-Perron matrix 𝒫l⁢m,l′⁢m′subscript𝒫𝑙𝑚superscript𝑙′superscript𝑚′caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-l italic-m PUNCT:, italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\cal P}_{lm,l^{\prime}m^{\prime}}, we (i) destroy unitarity, (ii) restrict the spectrum to N=(lm⁢a⁢x+1)2𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥12italic-N RELOP:equals OPEN:( italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN=(l_{max}+1)^{2} discrete eigenvalues whose moduli cannot exceed unity, and (iii) renounce the resolution of phase space structures of linear dimension below 4⁢π/(lm⁢a⁢x+1)4𝜋subscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥1italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:4 italic-pi ARG:end MULOP:divide OPEN:( italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:)\sqrt{4\pi}/(l_{max}+1). Upon diagonalizing the truncated N×N𝑁𝑁italic-N MULOP:times italic-NN\times N\,matrix 𝒫(N)superscript𝒫𝑁caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)} and increasing N𝑁italic-NN we find the “newly born” eigenvalues close to the origin while the “older” ones move about in the complex plane. “Very old” ones eventually settle for good. If the classical dynamics is integrable (τ=0𝜏0italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\tau=0 or βy=0subscript𝛽𝑦0italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\beta_{y}=0), the asymptotic large-N𝑁ADDOP:minus italic-N-N loci are back to the unit circle, where the full 𝒫𝒫caligraphic-P{\cal P} has its spectrum. But not so for a mixed phase space: while some eigenvalues of 𝒫(N)superscript𝒫𝑁caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)} “freeze” with unit moduli, others come to rest inside the unit circle as N→∞→𝑁italic-N ARROW:to ID:infinityN\to\infty. Table 1 illustrates how non-unimodular eigenvalues found for the kicked top with τ=10𝜏10italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:10\tau=10 at lm⁢a⁢x=40subscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥40italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:40l_{max}=40 remain in their positions as lm⁢a⁢xsubscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endl_{max} is increased to lm⁢a⁢x=50,60subscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥5060italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:50 PUNCT:, NUMBER:60l_{max}=50,60 and 7070NUMBER:7070.

We could pass over such findings and speak of the danger of tampering with infinity, were there not good reasons for and a physical interpretation of the existence of such stable non-unimodular eigenvalues.

The following qualitative argument suggests the persistence of non-unimodular eigenvalues as N→∞→𝑁italic-N ARROW:to ID:infinityN\to\infty for non-integrable dynamics. In contrast to regular motion, chaos brings about a hierarchy of phase space structures which extends without end to ever finer scales. A truncated Frobenius-Perron operator 𝒫(N)superscript𝒫𝑁caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)} must reflect the flow of probability towards the unresolved scales as a loss, however large the cut-off N𝑁italic-NN may be chosen.

Arguments from perturbation theory [13, 14] indicate that any non-unitary approximation to a unitary operator with continuous spectrum has some eigenvalues in positions near (non-unimodular) resonances of the unitary operator, i.e. poles of the resolvent in a higher Riemannian sheet. The perturbation series for such an eigenvalue does not converge but produces, with increasing order, a sequence of points concentrated in the neighborhood of the respective resonance. It is intuitive to interpret the freezing of non-unimodular eigenvalues (which need not be a strict convergence) as analogous to the “spectral concentration” known from perturbation theory.

To find further evidence for our interpretation of frozen eigenvalues as resonances we have looked at the eigenfunctions of 𝒫(N)superscript𝒫𝑁caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)}, with the following salient results. Eigenvalues freezing with unit moduli have eigenfunctions located on elliptic islands of regular motion surrounding elliptic periodic orbits in phase space. Such islands are bounded by invariant tori which form impenetrable barriers in phase space. We can thus expect the function constant inside the elliptic islands around a p-limit-from𝑝italic-p ADDOP:minusp-periodic orbit and zero outside to be an eigenfunction of 𝒫𝒫caligraphic-P{\cal P} with eigenvalue unity. Similarly reasoning we expect, for p>1𝑝1italic-p RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:1p>1, the p𝑝italic-ppth roots of unity to arise as eigenvalues as well; their eigenfunctions should have constant moduli and be invariant under 𝒫psuperscript𝒫𝑝caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{p}. For the kicked top with τ=4𝜏4italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:4\tau=4 and lm⁢a⁢x=60subscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥60italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:60l_{max}=60 an eigenfunction with the eigenvalue 0.99930.9993NUMBER:0.99930.9993, i. e. almost at unity, is shown in figure 1a. It is localized on the three islands around an elliptic orbit of period three (see figure 1b) and does have the two expected partners. We have indeed found frozen eigenvalues near the p𝑝italic-pp-th roots of unity and their eigenfunctions localized near elliptic period-p𝑝italic-pp orbits for p𝑝italic-pp up to 6; without much further effort such signatures of higher periods could be identified.

Now on to the eigenvalues freezing with moduli smaller than unity. Once such freezing has been observed the corresponding eigenfunction has approached its final shape on the resolved phase space scales. The eigenfunctions are sharply localized around unstable manifolds of hyperbolic periodic orbits, ones with low periods at first since these are easiest to resolve; but with growing lm⁢a⁢xsubscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endl_{max} more complex orbits of higher periods appear in the “support” of eigenfunctions. Even though all periodic orbits contributing to the structure of an eigenfunction have similar stability coefficients and even though the latter do describe the rate of mutual departure of neighboring trajectories it would be too naive to simply identify resonances with stability coefficients; we shall rather have to resort to cycle expansions further below.

Just as for the eigenvalues there is no strict convergence of the eigenfunctions. With increasing resolution new structures on finer scales become visible, in correspondence with the infinitely convoluted shape of the unstable manifolds (see figure 2a-b). Since no finite approximation 𝒫(N)superscript𝒫𝑁caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)} accounts for arbitrarily fine structures one encounters the aforementioned loss of probability from resolved to unresolved scales. Not even in the limit N→∞→𝑁italic-N ARROW:to ID:infinityN\to\infty can the unitarity of 𝒫𝒫caligraphic-P{\cal P} be restored: rather, the eigenfunctions tend to singular objects outside the Hilbert space, in tune with a continuous spectrum of 𝒫𝒫caligraphic-P\cal P.

The reader may have noticed that all eigenvalues in table 1 are real or almost imaginary. In fact, all eigenvalues we have identified as frozen inside the unit circle have phases corresponding to those of roots of unity, a fact demanding explanation. Clearly, since 𝒫(N)superscript𝒫𝑁caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)} is real the eigenvalues are either real or come in complex conjugate pairs, but no other phase than zero is distinguished by that argument. Again, the eigenfunctions offer further clues. We find that the phases of the complex eigenvalues are determined by the length p𝑝italic-pp of the shortest periodic orbit present in an eigenfunction f𝑓italic-ff as those of the p𝑝italic-pp-th roots of unity. The following intuitive argument indicates that this is to be expected.

Assume an eigenfunction is mostly concentrated around a shortest unstable orbit with period p𝑝italic-pp as well as a longer one with period p′superscript𝑝′italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endp^{\prime}. Denote by δp,nsubscript𝛿𝑝𝑛italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p PUNCT:, italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta_{p,n} a “characteristic function” which is constant near the n𝑛italic-nn-th point of the period-p𝑝italic-pp orbit, n=1⁢…⁢p𝑛1…𝑝italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 ID:ldots italic-pn=1\ldots p, and zero elsewhere. The truncated Frobenius-Perron operator 𝒫(N)superscript𝒫𝑁caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)} maps δp,nsubscript𝛿𝑝𝑛italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p PUNCT:, italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta_{p,n} into 𝒫(N)⁢δp,n=rp⁢δp,n+1superscript𝒫𝑁subscript𝛿𝑝𝑛subscript𝑟𝑝subscript𝛿𝑝𝑛1caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p PUNCT:, italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p PUNCT:, italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)}\delta_{p,n}=r_{p}\delta_{p,n+1} with the real positive factor rpsubscript𝑟𝑝italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{p} smaller than unity accounting for losses, in particular to unresolved scales. Independent linear combinations of the δp,nsubscript𝛿𝑝𝑛italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p PUNCT:, italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta_{p,n} can be formed as fp⁢k=∑n=1pei2⁢π⁢k⁢n/p⁢δp,nsubscript𝑓𝑝𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑝superscriptei2𝜋𝑘𝑛𝑝subscript𝛿𝑝𝑛italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start i2 italic-pi italic-k italic-n MULOP:divide italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p PUNCT:, italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:endf_{pk}=\sum_{n=1}^{p}{\rm e}^{{\rm i}2\pi kn/p}\delta_{p,n} with k=1⁢…⁢p𝑘1…𝑝italic-k RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 ID:ldots italic-pk=1\ldots p. Now consider a sum of two such functions, g=fp⁢k+fp′⁢k′𝑔subscript𝑓𝑝𝑘subscript𝑓superscript𝑝′superscript𝑘′italic-g RELOP:equals italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-k POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:endg=f_{pk}+f_{p^{\prime}k^{\prime}}, and apply 𝒫(N)superscript𝒫𝑁caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)}. For g𝑔italic-gg to qualify as an approximate eigenfunction we must obviously have rp≈rp′subscript𝑟𝑝subscript𝑟superscript𝑝′italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{p}\approx r_{p^{\prime}} and k/p=k′/p′𝑘𝑝superscript𝑘′superscript𝑝′italic-k MULOP:divide italic-p RELOP:equals italic-k POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endk/p=k^{\prime}/p^{\prime}. But then indeed 𝒫(N)⁢g≈rp⁢ei2⁢π⁢k/p⁢gsuperscript𝒫𝑁𝑔subscript𝑟𝑝superscriptei2𝜋𝑘𝑝𝑔caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-g RELOP:approximately-equals italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start i2 italic-pi italic-k MULOP:divide italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-g{\cal P}^{(N)}g\approx r_{p}{\rm e}^{{\rm i}2\pi k/p}g and [𝒫(N)]p⁢g≈rpp⁢gsuperscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝒫𝑁𝑝𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑝𝑝𝑔OPEN:[ caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-g RELOP:approximately-equals italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-g[{\cal P}^{(N)}]^{p}g\approx r_{p}^{p}g. The phase is thus dictated by the shortest orbit. Needless to say, the argument is identical to the one used before for the eigenfunctions living in islands around elliptic orbits, save for rp=1subscript𝑟𝑝1italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1r_{p}=1 in those regular cases. Since orbits of low period are most likely to be resolved first, the eigenvalues found for lm⁢a⁢x=40subscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥40italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:40l_{max}=40 in table 1 have phases according to p=1,2𝑝12italic-p RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2p=1,2 and 44NUMBER:44.

Knowing which orbits are linked to a non-unimodular eigenvalue, we can adopt a cycle expansion to calculate decay rates from periodic orbits [11]. A cycle expansion of the spectral determinant, i.e. the characteristic polynomial of the Frobenius-Perron operator, allows for the calculation of resonances in hyperbolic system with high accuracy [12]. The spectral determinant is expressed in terms of the traces of the Frobenius-Perron operator Tr⁢𝒫nTrsuperscript𝒫𝑛Tr caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\rm Tr}\;{\cal P}^{n} as d⁢(z)=∏n=1∞exp⁡(-znn⁢Tr⁢𝒫n)𝑑𝑧superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑛1superscript𝑧𝑛𝑛Trsuperscript𝒫𝑛italic-d OPEN:( italic-z CLOSE:) RELOP:equals SUMOP:product POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-n ARG:end Tr caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)d(z)=\prod_{n=1}^{\infty}\exp\left(-\frac{z^{n}}{n}{\rm Tr}\;{\cal P}^{n}\right) and subsequently expanded as a finite polynomial up to some order nm⁢a⁢xsubscript𝑛𝑚𝑎𝑥italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{max}. Only the first nm⁢a⁢xsubscript𝑛𝑚𝑎𝑥italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{max} traces are required for the calculation of this polynomial. The traces Tr⁢𝒫nTrsuperscript𝒫𝑛Tr caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\rm Tr}\;{\cal P}^{n} are calculated by summing over hyperbolic periodic orbits of length n𝑛italic-nn as Tr⁢𝒫n=∑1|det⁡(1-J)|Trsuperscript𝒫𝑛11𝐽Tr caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals SUMOP:sum FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start VERTBAR:| LIMITOP:determinant OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-J CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| ARG:end{\rm Tr}\;{\cal P}^{n}=\sum\frac{1}{|\det(1-J)|} where the 2×222NUMBER:2 MULOP:times NUMBER:22\times 2 matrix J=∂⁡Mn⁢(X)/∂⁡X𝐽superscript𝑀𝑛𝑋𝑋italic-J RELOP:equals OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-M POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X CLOSE:) MULOP:divide OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-XJ=\partial M^{n}(X)/\partial X is the linearized map Mnsuperscript𝑀𝑛italic-M POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM^{n} evaluated at any of the points of a contributing period-n𝑛italic-nn orbit and X=(cos⁡θ,φ)𝑋𝜃𝜑italic-X RELOP:equals OPEN:( TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-theta PUNCT:, italic-varphi CLOSE:)X=(\cos\theta,\varphi) the phase space point. The zeros of the polynomial which are insensitive against an increase of nm⁢a⁢xsubscript𝑛𝑚𝑎𝑥italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{max} are inverses of resonances.

The condition under which the ordinary cycle expansion of a spectral determinant converges is that all periodic orbits are hyperbolic and sufficiently unstable [2, 11, 12]. But if we only consider one ergodic region in phase space at a time, i.e. bar contributions from elliptic orbits, and impose a stability bound by including only the relatively few hyperbolic orbits identified in an eigenfunction of 𝒫(N)superscript𝒫𝑁caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)}, we can still use the cycle expansion as follows.We assume the spectral determinant factorized as d⁢(z)=∏i=1∞di⁢(z)𝑑𝑧superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1subscript𝑑𝑖𝑧italic-d OPEN:( italic-z CLOSE:) RELOP:equals SUMOP:product POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-z CLOSE:)d(z)=\prod_{i=1}^{\infty}d_{i}(z) with one factor disubscript𝑑𝑖italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endd_{i} for the family of eigenfunctions to which a given set of periodic orbits contributes. Each such factor di⁢(z)subscript𝑑𝑖𝑧italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-z CLOSE:)d_{i}(z) is then calculated separately with the above well known expressions but restricting the periodic-orbit sum for the trace Tr⁢𝒫nTrsuperscript𝒫𝑛Tr caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\rm Tr}\;{\cal P}^{n} to the orbits previously identified as contributing to the eigenfunctions. In table 2 resonances reproduced via the spectral determinant from only few orbits show surprisingly good agreement with the resonance-eigenvalues of 𝒫(N)superscript𝒫𝑁caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)} for τ=10𝜏10italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:10\tau=10 and lm⁢a⁢x=60subscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥60italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:60l_{max}=60. The index nm⁢a⁢xsubscript𝑛𝑚𝑎𝑥italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{max} gives the order up to which the spectral determinant is expanded, i.e. the length of the longest (pseudo-)orbits employed. The total number of orbits used is given in brackets behind the resonances. For the resonance 0.81030.8103NUMBER:0.81030.8103 the three relevant orbits of period 1,212NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:21,2 and 44NUMBER:44 are marked in the magnified region of the eigenfunction (lm⁢a⁢x=60subscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥60italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:60l_{max}=60) in figure 2c. The first repetition of the single period-2-orbit contributing to the resonance 0.65970.6597NUMBER:0.65970.6597 gives an almost diverging contribution to the spectral determinant, thus hindering its expansion to a higher order.

In the cycle expansion the phases of the resonances are reproduced exactly since they are again directly determined by lengths of orbits. If p𝑝italic-pp is the shortest orbit length used in di⁢(z)subscript𝑑𝑖𝑧italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-z CLOSE:)d_{i}(z), the polynomial can as well be written as a polynomial in zpsuperscript𝑧𝑝italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endz^{p} thus allowing the zeros to have the phases of the p𝑝italic-ppth roots of unity.

As a final check on the physical meaning of our frozen eigenvalues with moduli smaller than unity as Frobenius-Perron resonances we have compared these moduli with rates of correlation decay. In a numerical experiment we investigated the decay of the correlator C⁢(n)=[⟨ρ⁢(n)⁢ρ⁢(0)⟩-⟨ρ⁢(∞)⁢ρ⁢(0)⟩]⋅[⟨ρ⁢(0)⁢ρ⁢(0)⟩-⟨ρ⁢(∞)⁢ρ⁢(0)⟩]-1𝐶𝑛⋅delimited-[]delimited-⟨⟩𝜌𝑛𝜌0delimited-⟨⟩𝜌𝜌0superscriptdelimited-[]delimited-⟨⟩𝜌0𝜌0delimited-⟨⟩𝜌𝜌01italic-C OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPEN:[ OPEN:langle italic-rho OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:) italic-rho OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle ADDOP:minus OPEN:langle italic-rho OPEN:( ID:infinity CLOSE:) italic-rho OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle CLOSE:] MULOP:cdot OPEN:[ OPEN:langle italic-rho OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) italic-rho OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle ADDOP:minus OPEN:langle italic-rho OPEN:( ID:infinity CLOSE:) italic-rho OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle CLOSE:] POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endC(n)\!=\![\langle\rho(n)\rho(0)\rangle-\langle\rho(\infty)\rho(0)\rangle]\cdot% [\langle\rho(0)\rho(0)\rangle-\langle\rho(\infty)\rho(0)\rangle]^{-1}. Depending on the choice of ρ⁢(0)𝜌0italic-rho OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)\rho(0) different long-time decays are observable. We chose ρ⁢(0)𝜌0italic-rho OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)\rho(0) as covering the regions where the hyperbolic orbits relevant for a given resonance are situated. Figure 1c illustrates the very good agreement between the long-time decay of C⁢(n)𝐶𝑛italic-C OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:)C(n) (dots) and the decay as predicted by the corresponding resonance 0.810.81NUMBER:0.810.81 (full line). Together with the resonances at lm⁢a⁢x=60subscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥60italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:60l_{max}=60 table 2 displays the associated decay factors by which C⁢(n)𝐶𝑛italic-C OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:)C(n) decreases over one timestep, obtained from a numerical fit. Again the agreement is convincing.

In conclusion, we have presented a method to determine Frobenius-Perron resonances and the associated phase-space structures, applicable to systems with mixed phase spaces. The acquired knowledge of phase space structures allows to check the accuracy to which resonances are determined by the otherwise independent approaches of cycle expansion and correlation decay.

We are grateful to Shmuel Fishman for discussions initiating as well as accompanying this work. Support by the Sonderforschungsbereich “Unordnung und große Fluktuationen” and by the grant GAAV No. A1048804 of the Czech Academy of Sciences is thankfully acknowledged. F. H. also thanks the Isaac Newton Institute for hospitality during the workshop “Supersymmetry and Trace Formulae” in 1997 during which this work was begun; especially fruitful interactions with Ilya Goldscheid were made possible there.

M. R. Zirnbauer in: I.V. Lerner, J.P. Keating, and D.E. Khmelnitskii (eds.), Supersymmetry and Trace Formulae: Chaos and Disorder (Kluwer Academic, New York, 1999)
K.Pance, W. Lu, S. Sridhar, arXiv:nlin.CD/0004006
S. Fishman in: I.V. Lerner, J.P. Keating, and D.E. Khmelnitskii (eds.), Supersymmetry and Trace Formulae: Chaos and Disorder (Kluwer Academic, New York, 1999)
M. Khodas and S. Fishman, Phys. Rev. Lett. 84, 2837 (2000)
M. Khodas and S. Fishman, chao-dyn/9910040 (1999)
P. Cvitanović et al., Classical and Quantum Chaos: A Cyclist Treatise, (Nils Bohr Institute, Copenhagen, 1999) (www.nbi.dk/ChaosBook/)
F. Christiansen, G. Paladin, and H. H. Rugh, Phys. Rev. Lett. 65, 2087 (1990)
E. C. Titchmarsh, Proc. Roy. Soc. London Ser. A 210, 30 (1951)
M. Reed and B. Simon, Methods of Modern Mathematical Physics IV: Analysis of Operators (Academic Press, New York, 1978).

figure.figcaption: Figure 1: (a) The eigenfunction to the almost unimodular eigenvalue 0.99930.9993NUMBER:0.99930.9993 for τ=4,lm⁢a⁢x=60formulae-sequence𝜏4subscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥60italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:4 PUNCT:, italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:60\tau=4,l_{max}=60 is sharply localized on elliptic islands surrounding a period-33NUMBER:33-orbit in phase space. (b) Phase space portrait of the elliptic islands supporting the eigenfunction. (c) The decay of the correlator C⁢(n)𝐶𝑛italic-C OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:)C(n) (dots) [with the initial density localized in the region shown in figure 2c] and the decay predicted by the corresponding resonance 0.81030.8103NUMBER:0.81030.8103 (full line) agree well (see also table 2).

Figure 2: Eigenfunction to the resonance-eigenvalue 0.810.81NUMBER:0.810.81 for τ=10𝜏10italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:10\tau=10 and (a) lm⁢a⁢x=40subscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥40italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:40l_{max}=40, (b) lm⁢a⁢x=60subscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥60italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:60l_{max}=60. While the coarse structures are identical, finer structures appear in the eigenfunction with the higher resolution. (c) Magnification of the region of large amplitude in figure 2b. The numbers indicate the positions of the three periodic orbits of lengths 1,212NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:21,2 and 44NUMBER:44 which are used in the cycle expansion up to order nm⁢a⁢x=4subscript𝑛𝑚𝑎𝑥4italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:4n_{max}=4.

Below: corresponding results from cycle expansion up to order nm⁢a⁢xsubscript𝑛𝑚𝑎𝑥italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{max}. The total number of primitive orbits employed is given in curly brackets.
